title: Dielectric Response of the Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based Transformers
abstract: The interest in developing and testing dielectric nanofluids for electrotechnical purposes has increased significantly in the last ten years. A number of works have been published reporting dielectric and thermal properties for these liquids that enhance those of conventional insulating fluids. Some authors propose that the application of dielectric nanofluids to transformer insulation could improve the reliability of transformers and open new possibilities for transformer design. However, this will not be feasible until thorough studies on the interaction of these materials with other elements of the transformer, specially the solid insulation, are carried out. In this work, the effect of the presence of nanoparticles on the dielectric response of oil and oil-paper insulation is analysed in laboratory conditions. Specimens have been prepared to emulate the insulation system of transformers and the dielectric response in the frequency domain of these specimens has been characterized. The dependence of nanoparticle concentration on the dielectric response has been analysed. Proposing physical mechanisms that explain the experimental results observed over the oil and the paper samples. Some conclusions are extracted in this work that may be of interest if nanofluids are considered as liquid insulation for transformers.
full_text:
Received April 7, 2021, accepted May 4, 2021, date of publication May 24, 2021, date of current version June 16, 2021.
Digital Object Identifier 10.1 109/ACCESS.2021.3083368
Dielectric Response of the Oil-Paper Insulation
System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
DANIEL PÉREZ-ROSA
 , BELÉN GARCÍA
 , AND JUAN CARLOS BURGOS
Electrical Engineering Department, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid, 28911 Leganés, Spain
Corresponding author: Daniel Pérez-Rosa (daperezr@ing.uc3m.es)
This work was supported in part by the Spanish Ministry of Economy and Competitiveness under Grant DPI2015-71219-C2-2-R, and in
part by the Spanish Ministry of innovation under Grant PID2019-107126RB-C21.
ABSTRACT The interest in developing and testing dielectric nanoﬂuids for electrotechnical purposes has
increased signiﬁcantly in the last ten years. A number of works have been published reporting dielectric
and thermal properties for these liquids that enhance those of conventional insulating ﬂuids. Some authors
propose that the application of dielectric nanoﬂuids to transformer insulation could improve the reliability
of transformers and open new possibilities for transformer design. However, this will not be feasible until
thorough studies on the interaction of these materials with other elements of the transformer, specially the
solid insulation, are carried out. In this work, the effect of the presence of nanoparticles on the dielectric
response of oil and oil-paper insulation is analysed in laboratory conditions. Specimens have been prepared
to emulate the insulation system of transformers and the dielectric response in the frequency domain of these
specimens has been characterized. The dependence of nanoparticle concentration on the dielectric response
has been analysed. Proposing physical mechanisms that explain the experimental results observed over the
oil and the paper samples. Some conclusions are extracted in this work that may be of interest if nanoﬂuids
are considered as liquid insulation for transformers.
INDEX TERMS Dielectric response, nanoﬂuid, nanodielectric, nanoparticles, transformer insulation,
complex capacitance, FDS, Fe 3O4, permittivity.
I. INTRODUCTION
Power transformers are one of the most important compo-
nents of electrical systems. They are responsible of rising
the voltage level of the energy in order to transport it with
lower power losses and to reduce the voltage level near
to consumption points. The reliability of these elements is
vital for the adequate operation of the electrical network
and, in some cases, transformer faults have led to power
outages and severe accidents which derive in high economic
losses [1]–[3].
One of the main elements that makes possible the safe
operation of transformers is the insulation system, which is
divided into liquid and solid insulation. Transformer solid
insulation is composed of different types of cellulose based
materials such as Kraft paper and pressboard [4]. The liquid
insulation is commonly mineral oil (MO), which is derived
from petroleum, although other ﬂuids are starting to be used
such as natural and synthetic esters.
The use of nanodielectric ﬂuids (NF) as transformer liquid
insulation has been proposed by a number of authors in the
The associate editor coordinating the review of this manuscript and
approving it for publication was Hui Ma
.
last years [5]–[7]. Many experimental and theoretical works
have been conducted that show that the addition of small
concentrations of nanoparticles (NP) to insulating oils may
have a beneﬁcial effect on the dielectric properties of the
ﬂuids [8]–[10].
Most published studies are focused on the evaluation of
the breakdown voltages under AC or under impulse solicita-
tions. Increases up to 40 % in breakdown voltage have been
reported. The observed improvements have been explained
by the fact that impurities and charges present in the base ﬂuid
might be attracted by the NP limiting their role in the forma-
tion of the streamer. Then, higher voltage levels are required
to produce a breakdown [8], [11]–[13]. Another effect that
has been observed is that the presence of NP increases the
solubility of water in the base ﬂuid, limiting the hazardous
effect of the water on the breakdown voltage [14], [15].
Although there is a relatively high agreement in the fact
that NF have, in many cases, superior dielectric properties
than conventional oil, it should not be forgotten that, in case of
using these ﬂuids as transformer liquid insulation, they would
become a part of a complex system and would interact with
other transformer elements and materials. The interaction is
especially relevant in the case of the solid insulation.
VOLUME 9, 2021 This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 License. For more information, see https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/ 83797
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
The solid insulation of a transformer is devoted to elec-
trically separate regions of the equipment that operate at
different voltage level. It is constituted by thin insulation,
which is composed of Kraft paper that wounds the cooper
providing insulation between turns and discs; and thick insu-
lation, which is composed of pressboard cylinders and other
pressboard pieces and provides insulation between adjacent
windings and between the windings and other elements con-
nected to ground, as the magnetic core or the tank.
Both thin and thick insulation are made of cellulose, which
is a porous material. To improve the dielectric properties of
cellulose and extend its life, cellulose insulation is impreg-
nated with oil in a process that is generally done under
vacuum and at high temperatures after manufacturing the
transformer active part.
The effect of the NP on the properties of solid insulation
has not been fully studied, although it is a vital aspect in
the development and application of NFs in transformers. In a
previous work [16], the authors shown that there exist an
interaction between the cellulose ﬁbers and the NPs of the
NF that impregnates the solid insulation.
A few authors carried out experiments to evaluate the
breakdown properties of cellulose impregnated with NFs.
Zhou et al. [17] compared the AC and DC breakdown
voltage and the space charge distribution of pressboard
samples impregnated with a TiO 2 based NF and mineral
oil-impregnated pressboard. Other authors evaluated the
mechanical properties of the cellulose and its ageing process
when impregnated with NFs [18], [19].
The aim of the present work is to analyse the effect of
the NP in the dielectric response of cellulose when it is
impregnated with a Fe 3O4 based NF. The work includes
the characterization of the dielectric response of the NFs as
well. The dielectric response of an insulation is related with
the polarization processes that take place when a dielectric
material is subjected to an electric ﬁeld and has a key role
in the distribution of electric ﬁeld within the transformer.
The effect of the NP concentration is studied and physical
mechanisms that explain the experimental observations are
proposed in the paper. The measurement of the dielectric
response was carried out with Frequency Dielectric Spec-
troscopy (FDS) method. This technique provides information
about the conduction and the polarization processes that take
place when a dielectric material is subjected to an electric
ﬁeld. FDS characterizes the response of materials in a wide
frequency range what is important to separate processes with
different time constants.
II. DIELECTRIC RESPONSE OF OIL-PAPER INSULATION
A. POLARIZATION PROCESSES ON DIELECTRIC
MATERIALS
When a dielectric material is subjected to an electric ﬁeld,
a polarisation process starts consisting of the alignment of the
electric dipoles in the direction of the ﬁeld.
Unlike what happens in conductive materials, electric
charges in dielectrics materials are trapped and cannot move
freely. Polarisation processes in insulating materials are char-
acterised by a limited movement of the charges trapped in the
material and an orientation of the dipoles that constitute the
dielectric.
There are different mechanisms that contribute to the polar-
isation of dielectrics which are governed by different time
constants, such as the atomic polarisation, ionic polarisa-
tion, orientational polarisation, interfacial polarisation and
hopping.
If a voltage V(t) is applied across the plates of a capacitor
separated by a dielectric material, the resulting electric dis-
placement D(t) shows a time dependency that is related with
the retarded response of the different polarization processes
in the dielectric:
D(t) =ε0 ·E(t) +P(t) (1)
were ε0 is the permittivity of the vacuum, E(t) is the electric
ﬁeld and P(t) the polarization.
The instantaneous polarization of a material P(t) depends
on the so called dielectric response function, f(t), which is a
monotonous decreasing function that represents the response
of a material to an impulse electric ﬁeld.
For an impulse of magnitude E1t, the resulting polarisa-
tion would be:
P(t) =ε0 ·E ·1t ·f (t) (2)
For a ﬁeld with a different time dependency, E(t), the polar-
isation can be obtained as:
P(t) =ε0
∫ ∞
0
f (τ)E(t −τ)dτ (3)
The dielectric response function, f(t), depends on the prop-
erties of the materials and also on its condition. Factors as the
moisture content of a material or its aging condition have been
demonstrated to have an impact on its dielectric response.
Dielectric response measurements have been mainly used as
a diagnostic method for transformer oil-paper insulation, as
aging processes release water and other polar compounds that
impact the dielectric response of the insulation system.
B. DETERMINATION OF THE DIELECTRIC RESPONSE
Three methods are currently used to determine the dielec-
tric response of oil-paper insulation: The measure of the
Polarisation and Depolarisation Currents (PDC), the Recov-
ery V oltage Method (RVM) and the Frequency Dielectric
Spectroscopy (FDS) method. PDC and RVM determine the
response of the material in the time domain, while FDS
does it in the frequency domain [20]. Measuring equipment,
speciﬁcally designed to monitor the condition of transformer
insulation, are commercially available to perform RVM, PDC
and FDS measures.
FDS is the method applied in this work to obtain the
dielectric response of the NFs and the NF-impregnated cel-
lulose insulation. With this aim cylindrical capacitors with
each dielectric were prepared. A sinusoidal voltage of vari-
able frequency is applied to the capacitor in a typical range
83798 VOLUME 9, 2021
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
of 1000 Hz - 0.1 mHz. The equipment returns the complex
impedance of the capacitor for every applied frequency.
The dielectric material is modeled as a capacitor in par-
allel with a resistor (Fig. 1). The value of both parameters
(C and R) are frequency dependent. The resistor represents
the losses of active power, which are the sum of the resistive
losses (dependent on the material’s conductivity) and the
dielectric losses (i.e. the dissipation of energy caused by the
orientation of the dipoles).
FIGURE 1. Model to represent the insulation under study.
The relation between the phasor voltage and current is
given by Ohm’s law. Considering the association in parallel
of the impedances ZR and ZC :
ZR(ω) =R(ω) ZC (ω) =i ·XC (ω)
where
XC (ω) =− 1
ω·C(ω) (4)
For a certain applied voltage, the current is:
I(ω) =(i ·ω·C(ω) + 1
R(ω)) ·U(ω) (5)
The relation between the current and the voltage is com-
monly expressed as:
I(ω) =iωC0 ·(ε′(ω) −iε′′(ω)) ·U(ω) (6)
were ε(ω)′and ε(ω)′′are the real and imaginary parts of the
so called ‘‘complex permittivity’’ ( ˆε(ω)), which depend on
the capacitance and the dielectric losses of the material:
ε′=C(ω)
C0
ε′′= 1
R(ω) ·ω·C0
C0 is the geometric capacitance, which is deﬁned as the
capacitance of the test cell with any dielectric between the
electrodes.
Some other relevant magnitudes, such as the dielectric
dissipation factor, also called tan delta, can be derived from
these measures:
tan δ(ω) =ε′′(ω)
ε′(ω) (7)
Most FDS measuring devices provide the so called com-
plex capacitance as output parameter:
ˆC(ω) =C′(ω) +iC′′(ω) =C0 ·ˆε(ω) (8)
where
C′=C(ω) C′′= 1
R(ω) ·ω
As can be seen, C’ is the capacitance of the test object and
C’’ is proportional to the power loss of the material.
One of the limitations of FDS method, compared to other
methods such as PDC, is that it does not allow the direct esti-
mation of the conductivity of the material. However, at very
low frequencies the resistive part of the losses is predominant.
Cigré states that, when ε′′has slope ω−1 and ε′is constant it is
possible to identify the DC conductivity of the material with
the slope of the C’’ curve [20].
Dielectric measures are very sensitive to temperature vari-
ations. The temperature dependence of dielectric measure-
ments has been widely studied, observing that changes of
temperature cause a frequency shift of the dielectric response
frequency spectra, although in most dielectric materials, such
as oil-paper insulation, temperature does not affect signiﬁ-
cantly the shape of the dielectric response.
The shift of the dielectric response curves with temperature
can be expressed by means of an Arrhenius factor, and may be
calculated using the equation proposed by Ekanayake in [21]:
shift =log(ω1) −log(ω2) =− Ea
k ·2.3258 ·( 1
T2
− 1
T1
) (9)
where k is Boltzman’s constant and Ea is the activation energy
of the material.
All the dielectric response measurements presented in this
work were performed at constant temperature 30 oC. On
a second stage of the study the dielectric response of the same
specimens will be analysed at higher temperatures, closer to
the service temperatures of transformers.
III. EXPERIMENTAL PROCEDURE
A. MATERIALS
The commercial dielectric MO Nynas Nytro 4000× was used
as base ﬂuid to prepare the NFs characterized in this work.
Nynas Nytro 4000×is manufactured by the company Nynas
AB (Nynas AB, Stockholm, Sweden), and it is composed
of 70–90% hydrotreated light naphthenic hidrocarbons, and
10–30% lubricating oils (C20-50, hydrotreated neutral oil-
based) and less than 0.4% 2, 6-di-tert-butyl-p-cresol.
A custom made NP dispersion that contains Fe 3O4 NP
suspended in the MO Nynas Nytro to a concentration 60%
was used to prepare the NFs. The suspension was manufac-
tured by the company Magnacol (United Kingdom) using a
one-step manufacturing process, in which the NPs are directly
produced in the MO. The Fe 3O4 NPs present in the colloid
were about 10nm of diameter.
The speciﬁcations of the Kraft paper used to obtain the
cellulose-impregnated samples are: grammage 0.75 g/cm 3
and thermal class 105 ◦C. The typical composition of this type
of Kraft paper insulation is 75-85 % alpha cellulose 10-20 %
hemicellulose and 2-6 % lignin [22]
VOLUME 9, 2021 83799
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
B. NF PREPARATION
The NFs are prepared by mixing the base MO Nynas Nytro
4000×with the Fe 3O4 dispersion to three different concen-
trations: 0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 g/L. The mixture was performed
using an ultrasound stirrer (Inc model VC 750 Watt, manufac-
tured by Sonics& Materials). The sonicator was used at 40%
of its rated power (i.e., power 300 W and ultrasound wave
intensity 268 W/cm2), for two hours in intervals of 30 seconds
of agitation and 30 s of pause to avoid overheating of the
mixture. The NF stability was evaluated in a previous work,
in which the long-term stability of the NF was investigated
within a temperature range 20-110 ◦C using visual inspection
and measurement of the particle size with Dynamic light
scattering [23], concluding that the prepared NFs remained
stable at ambient temperature for more than one year with a
typical distribution of NP diameter between 10 and 16 nm.
C. PREPARATION OF THE TEST SPECIMENS
The main goal of this work is to characterize the dielectric
response of the NFs and also the response of pieces of cellu-
lose insulation impregnated with those NF. The responses of
the NF and nanocomposites are compared with the responses
of the MO and the MO-impregnated cellulose.
The responses of the MO and the NFs with different con-
centrations of NP were measured using a test cell for liquids
with cylindrical electrodes (Fig.2). The cell was ﬁlled with
2 cl of the ﬂuid that is being characterized in each test.
FIGURE 2. Liquids’ test cell.
The dielectric response of the solid insulation was tested
using a cylindrical test object. The objects were prepared
by rolling layers of Kraft paper around an aluminium core
using a winder machine to this end (Fig. 3). Identical test
objects were obtained with thickness of cellulose 1 mm; for
that purpose 14 layers of Kraft paper were necessary. The
resulting test object is shown in Fig.4.
The impregnation process of the cellulose insulation was
performed under vacuum, using the impregnation plant
shown in Fig. 5. The plant was designed to emulate the
impregnation process of the solid insulation that is carried out
in transformer factories. The test specimens are introduced
FIGURE 3. Winder machine deployed to prepare the solid insulation
test-specimens.
FIGURE 4. Cellulose test specimen and test cell.
in the vessel labeled as Chamber 2 in Fig. 5 and vacuum
is applied. At the same time the impregnating liquid (NF
or mineral oil) is placed in Chamber 1 and preheated to a
temperature of 40◦C. When the temperature is stable, the ﬂuid
is loaded in the hosepipe an introduced in Chamber 2. The
vacuum applied in Chamber 2 makes the NF ﬂow as a spray,
making the impregnation process similar to the one used
for transformers’ production. The ﬂuid is kept in Chamber
2 for 30 minutes to allow correct impregnation, and then it is
drained through a valve at the bottom of Chamber 2. In the
last step the test specimen is removed from Chamber 2.
Three groups of two test specimens were prepared by
the impregnation process. Each group was impregnated with
MO, NF 0.2 g/L, NF 0.3 g/L or NF 0.4 g/L. One of the test
specimens of each group was used to study the dielectric
properties, and the other one was used as a control sample
for moisture measurement.
In a previous work, samples of cellulose that were impreg-
nated with different NFs were tested using Cryo-SEM
microscopy [16] and other analytical techniques as Energy
Dispersive X-ray Spectrometry and Inductively coupled
Plasma Mass Spectrometry. That study proved that, when
cellulose is impregnated with a NF, some NPs penetrate in the
83800 VOLUME 9, 2021
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
FIGURE 5. Impregnation plant.
FIGURE 6. Cryo-SEM image of a NF-impregnated sample of cellulose.
cellulose creating bonds with the nanoﬁbres that constitute
its internal structure. Fig. 6 shows a Cyo-SEM image of a
NF-impregnated sample of Kraf-paper where it is possible to
observe the cellulose nanoﬁbres and the NPs.
The dielectric response of paper and oil insulation is
strongly dependent on the moisture content of the materi-
als [20]. Thus, in order to separate the effect of the moisture
TABLE 1. Moisture content of the oil and cellulose samples after the
preparation process.
from that of the NPs, the initial moisture content of the
samples included in the study was characterized using Karl
Fischer titration [24]. As it can be seen in Table 1, all the sam-
ples had similar low moisture contents after the preparation
process.
To characterize the dielectric response of the cellulose test
specimens they were ﬁtted into a teﬂon tank ﬁlled with oil
or with NF (depending on the cellulose-impregnating ﬂuid),
so that the whole test object was immersed in oil, as happens
with the solid insulation in operating transformers.
The aluminium core of the specimen was used as ground
electrode during the measurements, and a second aluminium
electrode was fastened to the external layer of the Kraft paper
to be used as measuring electrode. The electrode placed on the
test specimen was a 2 layers aluminium paper. The election
of this electrode is motivated because of its fair conductivity
and its capacitance to ﬁt on the dielectric testing specimens
produced for the present investigation.
The test specimens were kept at constant temperature for
at least 24 h prior to performing any dielectric response
measurements.
D. DIELECTRIC MEASUREMENTS SETUP
The frequency dielectric response of the cellulose test spec-
imens and the ﬂuids under study was measured using the
dielectric response analyser Dirana (Omicron, Austria). The
testing procedure is described below.
In all cases, the measurements were done under a con-
trolled temperature 30 ◦C, thus the test cells were placed
inside of an oven as is explained below.
1) SOLID INSULATION SAMPLES
The measurement protocol used to analyze the solid-
insulation samples applies a measuring voltage of 20 V and
a frequency range from 0.1 mHZ to 1 kHz. Although the test
equipment is able to measure both in the time domain or in
the frequency domain, all the measures were performed in
frequency domain.
The teﬂon cell containing the cellulose test specimen was
placed in the oven, which was set at the test temperature
for 24 hours for sample conditioning. Then, the setup of the
Dirana tester was connected to the cell as shown in Fig.7. The
measuring conﬁguration was Ungrounded Specimen Test
(UST). The cell was kept in the oven during the FDS tests
to ensure a constant temperature.
VOLUME 9, 2021 83801
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
FIGURE 7. Measurement setup for the cellulose test specimens.
2) LIQUID INSULATION
The liquid insulation samples were placed in a vacuum oven
Binder VD 53 at temperature 30 ◦C and vacuum of 1 mbar
for 24 hours prior to the dielectric measurements. After the
conditioning process the samples of the liquid were placed in
the test cell of liquids and were kept in the oven at 30 ◦C for
24 h before performing the measurement.
As with the solid insulation, the measurements of the
dielectric response of the ﬂuids were performed using the
Dirana FDS-PDC dielectric insulation analyzer. The mea-
surement protocol used to analyze the liquid insulation sam-
ples uses a measuring voltage of 50 V and a frequency range
from 1 mHz to 1 kHz. Although the test equipment is able to
measure both in the time domain or in the frequency domain,
all the measures were performed in the frequency domain.
IV. RESULTS AND DISCUSSION
This section presents the results of the FDS measurements
that were carried out in all the tested materials. Firstly,
the dielectric responses of the three prepared NFs are com-
pared with that of the MO used as base liquid. A discussion
is provided aiming at describing the physical processes that
take place in those materials to justify the experimental obser-
vations. Then, the results obtained on NF-impregnated paper
specimens are analyzed and compared with the recordings on
MO-impregnated paper samples.
A. DIELECTRIC RESPONSE OF THE MO AND THE NFs
As explained before, the dielectric response of the MO and
the NFs prepared with NP concentrations 0.2 g/L, 0.3 g/L
and 0.4 g/L was measured in the frequency domain, within
a rage 10 3 to 10−3 Hz. The results of the real and imaginary
parts of the complex capacitance in those materials are shown
in Figs. 8 and 9. These results are in agreement with the
observations of Dai on SiO 2 based NFs [9]
Fig.8 shows the real part of the complex capacitance for
the base MO and the NFs with NP concentrations 0.2, 0.3 g/L
and 0.4 g/L. It can be noted that the presence of NPs causes an
increase on the values of the real part of the complex capac-
itance in the whole frequency range; the change is higher at
lower frequencies.
FIGURE 8. Real part of the complex capacitance of MO and NFs vs
frequency.
FIGURE 9. Imaginary part of the complex capacitance of MO and NFs vs
frequency.
TABLE 2. Dielectric constant (εr ) of the MO and the NFs at 50 Hz.
The measured dielectric constant (ε r ) of the three ﬂuids is
shown in Table 2. As can be seen, there is an increase of more
than 45% in the permittivity value; the increase is higher as
the concentration of NP rises. The same pattern was reported
by Du et al. in [25] for several temperatures and with different
types of NPs and various NP concentrations.
To understand the behaviour of C′, it is important to
remark that the Fe 3O4 NP are polar compounds. Then if a
NFs is subjected to an electric ﬁeld, a charge displacement
takes place within the NPs that contributes to the overall
polarization of the ﬂuid. Because of this additional charge
displacement, the capacitance values recorded for the NFs are
higher than the ones measured in the MO. The polarization of
conductive NPs is a fast event; the time constants associated
83802 VOLUME 9, 2021
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
FIGURE 10. Resistivity of the MO and the NFs.
to the phenomena are much shorter than the ones associated
to atomic or molecular polarization in the oil. This explains
the fact that the effect of NP on C′is equally noticeable in the
whole frequency range.
Regarding imaginary part of the capacitance i.e. the dielec-
tric losses of the ﬂuids, which are displayed in Fig.9, clear
differences are observed between the measurements on the
NF samples and those on the MO. The overall value of
the dielectric losses is increased when adding NPs to the
base MO, but the increase is especially noticeable at lower
frequencies.
Apart from the polarization phenomena that take place in
the NPs, the observed increase of the dielectric losses can be
related with three different factors:
1) When conductive NPs are added to a base ﬂuid, its
conductivity increases signiﬁcantly.
In a previous work, the authors characterized the resis-
tivity of several Fe3O4 based NFs ﬁnding the behaviour
shown in Fig. 10. As it can be seen, the resistivity
of the MO was divided by 2.5 when 0.2 g/L of NP
were added and by 8 when the concentration increased
up to 0.35 g/L. As the resistivity of the NFs drops,
the formation of ionic paths is more likely, what leads
to an increase of the resistive losses. This effect is
dominant at very low frequencies [20].
2) The addition of NPs increases the polarization losses
caused by the interfacial polarisation in the interfaces
between the NPs and the base ﬂuid.
Since the electrical properties of the oil and the NPs
differ greatly, an accumulation of change takes place
in the interfaces between the two media when the
material is subjected to an electric ﬁeld. The formation
of this structure of counter-ions, which is commonly
referred to as the ‘‘electrical double layer’’ contributes
to increase the dielectric losses of the material.
3) Swartz [26] described an additional mechanism that
increases the dielectric losses of colloidal materials at
low frequencies. As the polarization of the dielectric
material progresses (i.e as the oil is polarized) there is
a certain displacement of the counter-ion layer which is
typically formed around the NPs when the NF is sub-
jected to an electric ﬁeld. The electrical double layer
suffers a polarization in which the ions are not removed
from the surface of the NPs, as this would require larger
amounts of energy to overcome the potential well, but
they move within the surface of the NPs, deforming
the double layer. Those movements lead to a further
increase of the dielectric losses.
B. DIELECTRIC RESPONSE OF THE NF-IMPREGNATED
CELLULOSE
Figs. 11 and 12 show the real and imaginary parts of the com-
plex capacitance of cellulose specimens that were impreg-
nated with MO and NFs prepared with NP concentrations
0.2, 0.3 and 0.4 g/L according to the process explained in
section III.
FIGURE 11. Real part of complex capacitance vs frequency for MO and NF
impregnated paper.
FIGURE 12. Imaginary part of complex capacitance vs frequency for MO
and NF impregnated paper.
As it can be seen, the impregnation of the cellulose with
NFs has a signiﬁcant impact on the dielectric response of the
VOLUME 9, 2021 83803
D. Pérez-Rosaet al.: Dielectric Response of Oil-Paper Insulation System in Nanofluid-Based transformers
solid insulation. A shift towards higher frequencies can be
observed for both components of the complex capacitance
which increases with the concentration of NPs dispersed
in the impregnating ﬂuid. These type of relaxation peaks
have also been observed on pressboard and paper samples
impregnated with MO that contained high concentrations
of moisture [20]. The shared polar character of water and
NPs might justify the similarities between the pattern of the
dielectric response of both types of specimens.
In a previous work [16], the authors carried out
Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy (FTIR) and X-Ray
fotoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis on samples of
NF-impregnated cellulose ﬁnding evidences of the existence
of bonds between the oxygen molecules of the cellulose and
the Fe atoms of the NPs. The fact that bonds exist between the
cellulose ﬁbres and the NPs, and the limitation on the NPs
mobility caused by those bonds has probably an impact on
the dielectric response of NF-impregnated cellulose and may
explain the different impact of the NPs in the response of the
solid and liquid insulation.
Additionally, a change of slope appears in the dielec-
tric losses of the three NF-impregnated specimens which
indicates that an additional relaxation process appears in
those specimens. The change of slope is more noticeable
for the specimens impregnated with NP of concentrations
0.3 and 0.4 g/L.
The dielectric constants of the cellulose specimens are
shown in Table 3. The value of this parameter shows a great
variability as the impregnation liquid changes and do not fol-
low a consistent tendency. A signiﬁcant increase is observed
for the cellulose specimens impregnated with NFs with low
concentration of NPs (0.2 g/L), but the measured relative
permittivity drops for the samples impregnated with liquids
with higher concentations of NPs reaching values closer to
those of the oils in the case of the NF 0.3 g/L and similar to
those of the MO-impregnated cellulose for the NF 0.4 g/L.
TABLE 3. Dielectric constant (εr ) of the cellulose impregnated with MO
or NFs at 50 Hz.
More research would be needed to explain the recorded
behaviour, but the observations are probably related with the
relative inﬂuence of two phenomena that occur simultane-
ously in the NP-cellulose composites. As was explained in
section IV-A, the NPs are polar compounds and they polarize
in presence of an electric ﬁeld; this would contribute to
increase the capacitance and the relative permittivity of the
material. However, the polarized NPs cause a distortion of
the electrical ﬁeld that can give rise to a decrease of other
polarization processes in the cellulose, what would diminish
the measured capacitance. It is likely that the ﬁrst effect
predominates when the NPs’ content is low, but as the con-
centration increases the second gains more importance.
V. CONCLUSION
The dielectric response of NFs and NF-impregnated solid
insulation has been investigated in this paper observing that
the presence of NP has an important impact on the per-
mittivity and the dielectric losses both types of electrical
insulation.
The relative permittivity of solid and liquid insulation
vary when NPs are added to both materials; for the oil,
the pemittivity increases consistently as the concentration of
NPs increases. In the case of paper, the permittivity increases
for low concentrations of NP but larger increases in the
concentration of NP cause the permittivity to drop a little.
This is due to the fact that two physical phenomena coexists
in the dielectric: the polarization of the NPs attached to the
cellulose chains and the distortion of the electrical ﬁeld in the
solid because caused by the presence of polarized NPs. It will
be important to analyse the dielectric response of cellulose
materials when those are impregnated with NFs based in
semiconductive or insulating NPs in the future. It is likely
that the interaction of other types of NPs with cellulose, and
their impact on the dielectric response is different from the
observations of this work.
The values of the relative permittivities of the oil and
paper insulation has a role on the distribution of the electric
ﬁeld of a transformer and are taken into account for the
transformer design. For the NFs to be used in real trans-
formers in the future, studies will be needed to determine
the values of these parameters and probably some modiﬁ-
cations in the design of the oil-paper insulation would be
required.

DANIEL PÉREZ-ROSA was born in Madrid,
in 1989. He received the B.Sc. degree, in 2014,
the M.Sc. degree in chemistry from the Univer-
sidad Complutense de Madrid, in 2014, and the
M.Sc. degree in materials engineering from the
Universidad Carlos III de Madrid, Spain, in 2015,
where he is currently pursuing the Ph.D. degree
with the Electrical Engineering Department. His
main interest includes development of nanodielec-
tric ﬂuids for electrical applications.
BELÉN GARCÍA received the B.Sc. degree,
in 1998, the M.Sc. degree in physics from the
Universidad Complutense de Madrid, in 1998, and
the Ph.D. degree in electrical engineering from
the Universidad Carlos III de Madrid, in 2002.
Since 2004, she has been holding a senior lecturer
position with the Electrical Engineering Depart-
ment, Universidad Carlos III de Madrid. Her main
research interests include power transformer life
management and insulating materials.
JUAN CARLOS BURGOS received the B.Sc.
degree, in 1980, and the Ph.D. degree from the
Escuela Técnica Superior de Ingenieros Indus-
triales de Madrid, in 1987. He is currently a
Senior Lecturer with the Universidad Carlos III de
Madrid, Spain, where he has been working, since
1994. His main research interest includes power
transformer maintenance.
